metadata.variety_notes: Generic Camellia sinensis profile. For cultivar-specific tuning add cultivar overrides later.

location_profile.region_name: Kotagiri Hills, Nilgiris, Tamil Nadu, India

climate_summary.notes: Cool, high-rainfall hill climate suitable for Nilgiris tea cultivation; supports year-round plucking cycles with seasonal flushes.

optimal_soil_pH.effect_notes: Tea prefers strongly acidic soil; pH above ~6 may encourage flowering and reduce leaf quality. Acidification/liming actions should be applied with caution and based on soil test.

preferred_pct.notes: % organic carbon / organic matter is desirable; long-term organic amendments stabilise pH and nutrient supply.

soil_moisture.typical_irrigation_guidance: Maintain evenly moist, well-drained soil. Avoid waterlogging; ensure drainage on slopes.

establishment.description: 0–12 months after planting; root establishment and early canopy build
establishment.application_timing_notes: Split applications; first manuring 2 months after planting. Emphasise P placement to encourage root growth.

vegetative_maintenance.description: Established bushes between pruning cycles (main growth period for leaf yield)
vegetative_maintenance.application_timing_notes: Divide N into multiple split dressings coinciding with flushes; apply K and P as basal + split.

high_demand_plucking_flush.description: During active plucking/production flushes when leaf removal is high
high_demand_plucking_flush.application_timing_notes: Topdress N near active roots ahead of major flushes; consider foliar feeds if deficit is acute.

mature_low_input.description: Mature, older bushes maintained at conservative input levels
mature_low_input.application_timing_notes: Reduce N rates for low-yield objectives; maintain K to preserve leaf quality.

soil_test_interpretation.notes: Soil tests are reported differently across labs. Use your lab's conversion tables. The bands below are common regional guidance.

bands_kg_per_ha.note: Bands are indicative; always use local lab interpretation for final decisions.

soil_test_interpretation.ppm_to_kg_per_ha_note: If sensor returns ppm in soil solution, do not equate directly to kg/ha without calibration to local lab data.

expected_sensor_types.notes: Calibrate to lab results; sensors measure mineral N not total N.
Soil solution P is highly variable; rely on lab Bray/Olsen tests where possible.
Exchangeable K sensors exist; validate with lab flame photometer.
Direct reading is reliable if probe is maintained.
Useful to time fertilizer applications and avoid loss.

sensor_integration_spec.latest_reading_query_example: SELECT sensor_type, value, units, timestamp FROM sensor_readings WHERE plot_id = 'main_plot' ORDER BY timestamp DESC LIMIT 1
sensor_integration_spec.calibration_guidance: Pair sensor readings with periodic lab soil tests (every 3–6 months) and derive calibration factors for the plot. Perform at least 6 matched pairs (sensor vs lab) to build a calibration curve for Kotagiri's acidic, organic soils.

rule_set.description: Simple check for N deficit in flowering/production stage using numeric threshold.
rule_set.explanation: If available mineral N is below threshold for active growth, recommend N application.
rule_set.action_template: Yes. The sensor for the plot shows available nitrogen at {live_N}{units}, which is below the target {target_N}{target_units} for {growth_stage}. Apply a nitrogen supply equivalent to {suggested_N_rate_kg_per_ha} kg/ha (split into two applications during the next flushes). Suggested formulation: urea or ammonium sulfate; consider up to 30% replacement with validated biofertilizer if used.

Yes. The plot has low available phosphorus ({live_P}{units}). Apply rock phosphate or DAP as localized placement to reach the target {target_P} kg/ha. For strongly P-fixing Kotagiri soils, prefer placement/banding and organic P sources.
rule_set.notes: P-fixation common in acidic soils; placement improves availability.

rule_set.action_template: Yes. Potassium is low ({live_K}{units}). Apply muriate of potash (MOP) or sulfate of potash to reach target {target_K} kg/ha. Potassium supports shoot strength and leaf quality.

rule_set.description: Soil pH out of preferred band
rule_set.action_template: Soil pH is {live_pH}. Tea prefers pH 4.5–5.5. If pH < 4.2, consider cautious liming only after a lab-based recommendation. If pH > 6.0, investigate cause and consult extension; avoid alkaline amendments unless advised.

rule_set.description: Fallback when sensor types are missing or data are stale
rule_set.action_template: I can't make a confident nutrient recommendation because recent sensor data (N/P/K/pH) are missing or older than 7 days. Please trigger a new sensor reading or upload the latest lab soil test (date: {latest_lab_date}).

recommendation_style_guidelines.example_yes_response: Yes — nitrogen is deficient. Sensor: N={live_N}{units}; target for {growth_stage}: {target_N}{target_units}. Recommend applying {suggested_N_rate_kg_per_ha} kg/ha N (split into 2 applications over the next 4–6 weeks).
recommendation_style_guidelines.example_no_response: No — nutrient levels are within target ranges for the current growth stage. Continue routine manuring schedule and recheck sensors or lab test in 8–12 weeks or after heavy rains.

common_fertilizers.name: Urea
common_fertilizers.notes: Quick soluble N source; use split applications

common_fertilizers.name: DAP (Diammonium phosphate)
common_fertilizers.notes: Good P source; avoid seedling contact

common_fertilizers.name: MOP (Muriate of Potash)
common_fertilizers.notes: Common K source; apply away from collar

common_fertilizers.name: Rock phosphate
common_fertilizers.notes: Slow release P; recommended placement for acidic, P-fixing soils

unit_conversions.note: TNAU tables often give kg/acre; conversion factor used = 1 acre = 0.404686 ha.

operational_notes.safety_notes: Avoid broadcasting urea immediately before heavy rain to reduce leaching. For steep Kotagiri slopes, prefer banding and mulching to reduce runoff and nutrient loss.
operational_notes.organic_integration: Encourage green manures, composts and biofertilizers; validated biofertilizer use can replace part of chemical fertilizer needs (validate locally).

examples_and_sql_snippets.how_to_query_latest_readings: SELECT sensor_type, value, units, timestamp FROM sensor_readings WHERE plot_id = 'main_plot' ORDER BY timestamp DESC LIMIT 1;
examples_and_sql_snippets.how_to_get_crop_and_stage: SELECT crop_type, growth_stage FROM plots WHERE plot_id = 'main_plot' LIMIT 1;
